bibl.title: Letter from Joseph Y. Porter to Henry Rose Carter, January 16, 1914

div1.p: Porter thanks Carter for his educational malaria pamphlet for children.

div1.head: Letter from Joseph Y. Porter to Henry Rose Carter, January 16, 1914
div1.opener:
FORM 146
IN GOD WE TRUST
Joseph Y. Porter, M.D.
P/B State Health Officer.
Executive Office
State Board of Health of Florida
Jacksonville, Fla.,
January 16, 1914.
Dr. H. R. Carter,
Surgeon, U. S. Public Health Service,
Baltimore, Md.
My dear Carter:-
div1.p:
Your letter of January 8th with attached printed copy of your ma-
laria catechism has been received and my sincere thanks goes with this
acknowledgement. I have read the little pamphlet with a good deal
of interest and likewise with much instruction. It is an admirable
compilation and the questions and answers are made so plain that the
child cannot fail to understand exactly what is asked of him, and
what he is taught. I have already sent a copy to the Superintendent
of Public Instruction of the State who has acknowledged the same and
commends it as a text book for the school. I enclose a copy of his
letter so you will see what he has to say on the subject.

I enjoyed reading the typewritten portion of your letter, but not
so much as that which you add in your own hand writing, and I am sorry
you thought it necessary to interline “Doctor” before “Porter” because
I never thought you would be so formal. We are both at an age where
formality of that kind can be brushed aside and while we are not
boys in age, yet, we can be in spirit and call each other by name
without professional title.

If Professor Sheats, the Superintendent of Public Instruction
of the State, does not acquire these catechisms I propose to either
buy them from the public printer and distribute them myself from this
office, or else, will take your copy with your permission, of course,
and condense it somewhat, issuing it as one of the State Board of Health
bulletins written by you. I don't see that there will be any plagiarism
in doing this, and I certainly think you are entitled to a full need
of credit for the good work which you have done in this line, and
the plain way in which you have put the subject up to the children
of the State. After all, the benefits of personal hygiene and rural
sanitation must come from those who are now growing up into man-
hood and womanhood, because the older generation I find are very
hard to teach, and like old dogs learn new tricks very slowly.
There will be no trouble whatever to get the children interested in
this subject. In fact, the children here in Jacksonville have for
sometime hatched mosquitoes in the schoolroom under screened ves-
sels and the teachers have demonstrated the development of the mos-
quitoes from the egg. However, a catechism such as you have com-
piled will be wonderfully instructive and will simplify the work of
those who already have done a little teaching in this line.

Personally, I am in pretty fair health. My boy whom you may
remember as a little fellow is now practicing medicine in Key West
and doing the laboratory work of that section of the State.
#2.
When I was home for the Christmas holidays he gave me a good over-
hauling showing that my blood pressure is not too high and that
my kidneys are in good normal condition, neither sugar nor albumin
being found, not even a trace. The former you know is out of the
ordinary in a man of 67 years of age.

I was right sick last summer in Atlantic City when attending the
American Medical Association, but that was due more to personal neglect
I think than any organic trouble, for you know what occurs when sewers
are blocked and do not work properly.

I would be mighty glad to see you again down this way and hope
that you will sometime get a detail that will bring you around Key
West, and Jacksonville. Our old friends are getting remarkably
few and the old guard is decreasing in numbers very rapidly. When
I think of it it brings on a degree of sadness, but then there is
one compensating thought that we have both accomplished something and
perhaps mankind has been somewhat bettered that we have lived. Let
us hope so any how, however little it may be, it has helped.

With best and kindest regards and good wishes for the new year
both for health and professional success, I am,
